ma5:1.2: One time, the Buddha traveled to Kośala and stayed among the people there.
ma5:1.3: He traveled with a large assembly of monks and followers.
ma5:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān suddenly saw from the road a place where there was a large wood pile engulfed in flames.
ma5:2.2: After he saw this, the Bhagavān went down to the side of the road, spread out his sitting mat by a tree, and sat down cross-legged.
ma5:3.0: 1. The Burning Wood Pile and the Young Woman
ma5:3.1: After he had sat down, the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
ma5:3.2: “Do all of you see that large wood pile engulfed in flames?”
ma5:5.1: The Bhagavān again addressed the monks,
ma5:5.3: Suppose you were to embrace, sit, or lay with that large wood pile engulfed in flames.
ma5:5.4: Suppose there were a warrior woman or a priest, householder, or worker woman in the prime of life who is clean and perfumed, wearing bright and pure clothing, and whose body is adorned with flowers and jewelry, and you were to embrace, sit, or lay down with her.
ma5:6.2: “Bhagavān, that large wood pile is engulfed in flames!
ma5:6.3: If we embraced, sat, or lay with it, it would be very painful.
ma5:6.4: Bhagavān, suppose there were a warrior woman or a priest, householder, or worker woman in the prime of life who is clean and perfumed, wearing bright and pure clothing, and whose body is adorned with flowers and jewelry.
ma5:6.5: To embrace, sit, or lay with her would be very pleasant, Bhagavān.”
ma5:7.2: “I will explain this for you, so you trainees don’t lose the ascetic path.
ma5:7.3: Those of you who want to achieve the unsurpassed religious practice should rather embrace that wood pile engulfed in flames.
ma5:7.4: If you sit or lay down there even though it will cause you to suffer pain or die, you won’t be destined to go to a bad place or be born in hell after your body breaks up and your life ends.
ma5:8.1: “If a foolish man violates the precepts and doesn’t make effort, that creates bad and unskillful situations.
ma5:8.2: His is not the religious practice, but he calls it the religious practice.
ma5:8.3: He’s not an ascetic, but he’s called an ascetic.
ma5:9.1: “Suppose he were to embrace a warrior woman or a priest, householder, or worker woman in the prime of life who is clean and perfumed, wearing bright and pure clothing, and whose body is adorned with flowers and jewelry, or suppose he were to sit or lay down with her.
ma5:9.2: That foolish man’s long night will be neither good nor purposeful as a result, which brings the result of bad qualities.
ma5:9.3: He’ll be destined to go to a bad place or be born in hell when his body breaks up and his life ends.
ma5:10.1: “Therefore, all of you must examine your own goal, examine the goals of others, and examine the goals of both.
ma5:10.3: ‘My training as a renunciant is neither in vain nor empty; it has its fruit and its result.
ma5:10.4: There is an utmost happiness, birth in good places, and attainment of long life.
ma5:10.5: I accept the faithful gifts of others for clothing, food and drink, bed and bedding, and bathing and medicine.
ma5:10.6: It will cause my benefactors to obtain great fortune, obtain great rewards, and obtain great radiance.’
ma5:11.0: 2. The Hair Rope and the Massage
ma5:11.1: The Bhagavān again addressed the monks,
ma5:11.3: Suppose there’s a strong man who tightly wraps a cord of hair rope around your calf and twists it until it cuts your skin.
ma5:11.4: After cutting skin, it cuts your flesh.
ma5:11.5: After cutting flesh, it cuts your tendons.
ma5:11.6: After cutting tendons, it cuts your bone.
ma5:11.7: After cutting bone, it reaches your marrow and stops.
ma5:11.8: Suppose you were to accept a faithful gift from a warrior, priest, householder, or worker who massages your body, limbs, hands, and feet.
ma5:12.2: “Bhagavān, if a strong man tightly wrapped a cord of hair rope around our calves and twisted it until it cut our skin, and it cuts our flesh after cutting skin, cuts our tendons after cutting flesh, cuts our bones after cutting tendons, cuts our marrow after cutting bones, and stops, that would be very painful.
ma5:12.3: Bhagavān, suppose we were to accept a faithful gift from a warrior, priest, householder, or worker who massages our body, limbs, hands, and feet.
ma5:12.4: That would be very pleasant, Bhagavān.”
ma5:13.2: “I will explain this for you, so you trainees don’t lose the ascetic path.

ma5:13.4: Even though it will cause you to suffer pain or die, you won’t be destined to go to a bad place or be born in hell after your body breaks up and your life ends.

ma5:29.0: 5. The Hot Iron Ball and Delicious Meal
ma5:29.1: The Bhagavān again addressed the monks,
ma5:29.3: Suppose there’s a strong man who opens your mouth with hot iron forceps and then puts in it an iron ball that’s glowing and flaming hot.
ma5:29.4: That hot iron ball burns your lips.
ma5:29.5: After it burns your lips, it burns your tongue.
ma5:29.6: After it burns your tongue, it burns your gums.
ma5:29.7: After it burns your gums, it burns your throat.
ma5:29.8: After it burns your throat, it burns your heart.
ma5:29.9: After it burns your heart, it burns your intestines and stomach.
ma5:29.10: After it burns your intestines and stomach, it falls through [to the ground].
ma5:29.11: Suppose you were to accept a faithful gift of food with measureless flavors from a warrior, priest, householder, or worker.
ma5:30.2: “Bhagavān, if a strong man opened our mouths with hot iron forceps and then put in it an iron ball that’s glowing and flaming hot, that hot iron ball would burn our lips.

ma5:30.7: After it burns our heart, it would burn our intestines and stomach.
ma5:30.8: After it burns our intestines and stomach, it would fall through [to the ground].
ma5:30.10: Bhagavān, suppose we were to accept a faithful gift of food with measureless flavors from a warrior, priest, householder, or worker.
ma5:30.11: That would be very pleasant, Bhagavān.”
